subject: OT: RE: [junit] Re: JavaDocs
msgSnippet: If you remove the Javadocs from the code, they ll never get updated and will quickly become the useless docs that you hate. If you take an extra 30 seconds to
messageBody:
If you remove the Javadocs from the code, they'll never get updated
and will quickly become the useless docs that you hate. If you take an extra
30 seconds to keep your Javadocs up to date when you make any changes to a
class's methods, you'll find they're not a pain at all. If you wait until
you're finished coding then try to put them all in, though, I can see why
you'd hate them.

And what's wrong with having them in the code? Do you not believe in
comments, either? Javadocs provide a nice structure for commenting methods
and classes, better than the random comment formats you typically see in
C/C++ coding.

-tim

-----Original Message-----
From: ericheikkila [mailto:ericheikkila@...]
Sent: Monday, February 18, 2002 3:26 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] Re: JavaDocs


Hmm...ok...slight addendum...I do happen to like being able to open
up a web page provided with something download from sourceforge and
being able to quickly browse through to answer a specific question
(like how do I call X within this class I downloaded). So I suppose
they have their uses. I just don't want my code cluttered with the
stuff. I'd rather run some tool against my clean code that generates
the HTML pages for me (which are out there...and/or built into
several of the IDEs currently in use).

-Eric

--- In junit@y..., Eric Heikkila <ericheikkila@y...> wrote:
> I hate documentation in general...most of it sucks,
> and the stuff that doesn't suck is usually either
> useless or out of date. I'd rather have the unit
> tests than javadocs any day. ;)
>
> -Eric
>
> --- "Stevens, Timothy J. (LNG-MBC)"
> <timothy.j.stevens@l...> wrote:
> >
> > Why do you hate Javadocs, out of curiosity? I think
> > they're a great
> > tool for easy documentation.
> >
> > -tim
> >
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: Eric Heikkila [mailto:ericheikkila@y...]

> > JAVADOCS!!!????
> >
> > AHHH!!...RUN AWAY!!!!!
> >

> > wrote:
> > > The javadoc task doesn't support the nested
> > > "fileset" element. At least not
> > > the one that I have.
> > >
> >
> > NESTING!!?? IN JAVADOCS?? RUN AWAY FARTHER!! ;)
> >
> > hehe..needless to say, I really can't stand java
> > docs.
> > What is it you're trying to document? Do you
> > REALLY
> > need to use these, or is there a better way?
> >
> > BTW - Just posing the question...don't have any
> > answers right now. Really just wanted to see what
> > other people thought about it.
> >
> > -Eric
